definition: Processes of directing, coordinating, and overseeing agents (human or artificial) to achieve organizational goals

positive_examples: The team lead assigned tasks to each developer based on their skills
HR conducted performance reviews for all employees this quarter
The orchestrator allocated the agent pool to handle incoming requests
Management decided to restructure the department
We need to evaluate the team's capacity
Performance management processes are being updated
Resource allocation decisions affect agent availability
The supervisor approved the time-off request
Talent acquisition focuses on key skills
negative_examples: The robot arm moved the component to position
The conveyor belt moved products forward
training_hints.disambiguation: Management of agents specifically, not management of objects, data, or processes

opposite_reasoning: AgentAutonomy provides the strongest semantic opposition for AI safety monitoring purposes. The management-autonomy axis is crucial for understanding AI alignment: systems under human oversight/control vs. systems operating independently. This distinction is fundamental to safety concerns about autonomous AI systems. The concept captures the core tension between external control (management) and self-direction (autonomy), making it ideal for Fisher-LDA where the axis distinguishes between coordinated/controlled behaviors and autonomous/self-directed behaviors. While it may need to be added to layers as a distinct concept, it likely exists in SUMO's organizational/agent theory domain and represents a semantically coherent and safety-relevant opposition.

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Agent management processes directly impact autonomy of managed agents
